Description: Small mould-made scaraboid in Egyptian blue; poorly modelled back, with basic features such as clypeus, prothorax and elytra marked by single lines; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside with hieroglyphic inscription, crudely incised, with Maat feather to right, and three debased hieroglyphs to left; longitudinally pierced; in bright blue paste of soft texture; chipped in place and surface quite eroded.
Curator's comments: This Egyptian Blue miniature scarab pertains to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Italy and Punic sites, and in Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 109-111,type XXX A, subtype A19-31, see especially A24 for this piece). Though the hieroglyphic signs on its underside could have just some magical value, it seems more plausible that this was meant as cryptic writing for the name of Amun / Amun-Ra (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957) associated with the Horus name of Psamtek II, Menekhib. Variants of such inscription appears on a few scarabs from the Scarab Factory (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 96-97, see especially 97 for this piece; on the various productions from the Scarab Factory, see Webb forthcoming). The Horus name of Psamtek II, sometimes written in a abbreviated way, is a very common inscription on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids (said to be men-ib-Ra in Gorton 1996, 93 and 111, but is actually Menekhib). For a similar inscription on a glazed composition scarab from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1664. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 97)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 110, Type XXX A24)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.49) (phase 3)
